level 6TheLastSamurai101 Â· 10 hr. agoThis is not how sanctuary cities/states work if that's what you're talking about. Sanctuary cities are just cities where the local police don't get involved in actively reporting or catching illegal immigrants or cooperate with operations against illegal immigrants. They argue that it is actually not their job to do so anyway, but legally the responsibility of the immigration authorities and federal police. The purpose is so that illegal immigrants aren't afraid to access things like legal, social, educational and health services for fear of deportation.Republicans have created this false narrative that santuary cities actively protect illegal immigrants from the immigration authorities, but that is not true. ICE can still operate freely within places like New York City, investigate however they like and catch whoever they want. It is just that the NYC police and the NY state police won't help them. level 4BigWetRasogolla Â· 19 hr. agoUSA <-> West BengalEven with university or job you are stuck in H1B if you are Indian.It's really a battle, isn't it?I'm a U.S. citizen, and my wife is Indian. But such requests are very rarely granted, and many families have to live separately--one spouse in India, the other in the U.S.--until all formalities have concluded.And then, on the other hand, I have Indian friends who don't have permanent residency after having spent between 10 and 15 years in the United States. level 7BigWetRasogolla Â· 11 hr. agoUSA <-> West BengalSo consular processing itself isnâ€™t very time-consuming â€”itâ€™s all the formalities that come before and after.The worst step is, by far, the worst. Every immigrant visa application must be preceded by the submission of Form I-130. This application is sent to the United States and reviewed by U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, which makes a determination and forwards its decision to the Department of State.Processing times vary, with different USCIS field offices having wildly different averages. Some centers take a year, others take closer to two. Itâ€™s all luck (or lack thereof).After Form I-130 has been processed, it only takes another few monthsâ€”up to a half-yearâ€”to complete all other formalities.My wife and I went through â€œdirect consular filing,â€ or DCF. In DCF, the consulate itself reviews and adjudicates Form I-130 (along with the subsequent documentation that would typically be reviewed by the National Visa Center). Most of the time, DCF can be completed within a matter of weeks. Our case only took as long as it did because we were also planning our social wedding (weâ€™d had a registry marriage the year before).However, very, very few people get to go through DCF. You have to meet specific requirements, and the decision to accept or deny a request is entirely at the consulateâ€™s discretion.2ReplyShareReportSaveFollow
